awd_titl_txt: TWC: Small: Collaborative: Characterizing the Security Limitations of Accessing the Mobile Web
awd_abstract_narration: Mobile browsers are beginning to serve as critical enablers of modern computing. With a combination of rich features that rival their desktop counterparts and strong security mechanisms such as TLS/SSL, these mobile browsers are becoming the basis of many other mobile apps. Unfortunately, the security guarantees provided by mobile browsers and the risks associated with today?s mobile web have not been evaluated in great detail. This project investigates the security of mobile browsers, the applications that build on them through APIs such as WebViews and the mobile specific websites they access. This research differs significantly from prior work; whereas previous research has focused largely on stand-alone, third-party applications, our work focuses on mobile browsers and the increasing number of applications using them as their basis for delivering content. Moreover, our work measures the extent to which the mobile web itself is vulnerable. The combination of these efforts aims to create the first longitudinal and principled study of the mobile web ecosystem.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: The focus of this award was to measure and improve the security of the mobile web. Given that the number of mobile web browsers now exceeds the number of traditional browsers, it is expected that the number of attacks focused on the mobile space will increase. 

The first thrust of the work, mobile browsers and the mobile web, focused both on shortcomings in mobile browser security and in measuring malicious websites specifically targeting them. We demonstrated that not only were mobile browsers far less consistent about the implementation of proper security posture, but that limited screen space dramatically impacted if and how such information was reported to users. We also discovered that mechanisms designed to detect traditional malicious web pages failed in the mobile space due to significant differences in hosting characteristics.

Our second thrust of this work investigated the security of other mobile applications. This additional effort was necessary to determine if developers were making similar poor security decisions in such applications. For instance, whereas a mobile browser connecting to a website with poorly configured cryptographic protection may warn a user, an application rendering the same content would fail to do so. This thrust resulted in a number of important results, culminating in a large-scale overview of the efforts by the research community in the application security space. We were able to conclude that significant problems remain to be addressed, and that work focused on getting the basic mechanisms of security properly configured would be particularly useful. It is expected that this document will help set the research agenda for the community in the next few years.

Both of these trusts resulted in a number of papers published in top academic conferences and journals (the details of which are included in the full report). A number of vulnerabilities found in this work were also addressed directly by vendors to improve the security of their software.

Broader Impact: One of the biggest successes of this work was the number of students exposed to research. Over 15 students at the University of Florida (and Georgia Tech before PI Traynor moved to UF) and North Carolina State University were able to work on projects sponsored by this grant. These students include graduates and undergraduates, many of whom are from underrepresented groups. Many of these students have since graduated, and noted that it was their work on these projects that made the biggest difference to companies looking to hire them.

Modified by: William H Enck
